child:
Divides his last penny. He is later helped by the grateful person. *Types 508,
592, 665; BP II 490ff., Scala Celi 81b No. 467; *Hibbard 73, 79; Alphabet No.
291; Japanese: Anesaki 320.
Child divides last loaf with fairy (witch, etc.).

Man who divides his food with beggar is later freed from
captivity by him.
Excessive hospitality causes chieftain to become poor.
Reward for providing coffins for poor.
Generosity to saint (god) in disguise rewarded.

(Cf. †Q1, †Q45.1.)
Alphabet Nos. 297, 344, 365; Scala Celi 39b No. 222; Irish: Beal XXI 304, 325,
O‘Suilleabhain 2, 68; Spanish: Keller,
Espinosa II No. 86, III Nos. 168--171, Espinosa Jr. Nos. 83--85, 181f., 210;
India: *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 485; Chinese: Graham.

rewarded when slave becomes king. Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.
Slave freed as reward for killing enemy’s two slaves,

and given as much land as he can cultivate in three days.
Icelandic: *Boberg.
Reward for generosity to king‘s buffoon.

Ruler rewards herald who is generous to his buffoon.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Reward for tearing out eye when demanded.

Saint gives a man all his credit for good deeds so that the
man may go to heaven.

Saint is then rewarded with even greater credit. (Cf. †Q172.)
Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Cobbler gives new pair of shoes to poor boy and says: “You
can pay me when you become archbishop.”
Generously rewarded many years later. India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
(Cf. †L200.) Irish myth: Cross; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Jewish: Neuman.
child: Monk who did not ask for position made abbot.

He is given the bribe
money paid by other ambitious monks. Wesselski Mönchslatein 124 No. 107; India:
Thompson-Balys.
Devil spares abbot because of humility.

Fra Lippo Lippi is freed by Moors because of his greatness
as a painter.
Princess kisses ugly poet while he sleeps.

Kisses not the ugly face but the divine mouth. Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

content: Icelandic: *Boberg; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda.
child: Disguised king rewards rescuer from robbers.

Magic shirt and information about sought robbers as reward
for rescue of poor fisherman.
Plenty of fishes as reward for rescue.

Maiden queen offers her hand as reward for rescuing her
town.

Maiden gives her hand and riches to man who rescues her
from trap.
Humility before saint (god) in disguise rewarded.

content:
Reward given by devil or ghost. *Type 326; Penzer VII 120 n. 2; Irish myth:
*Cross; Icelandic: Boberg; India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda.
child:
Snake helps girl who permits it to wind itself around her
body.

Africa (Rozwi): Posselt Fables of
the Veld (London, 1929) 39ff., (Thonga): Junod 248ff., Berthoud ZsES XXI 154f.
No. 10.

Ferocious animal (lion, tiger, etc.) rewards man who does
not fear it.
India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 845.

Nobleman’s perseverance wins him coveted place on reserved
bench.

Elected upon the death of one of
its occupants. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content:
Hdwb. d. Märchens II 66a; India:
*Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers 567.
child:
Ant has food all winter because she keeps it safe and dry
by airing it in the sun. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman, Moreno Esdras.
child: Ruler marries maiden who has repulsed his advances.
Spurned ruler has the maiden marry highest ranking knight.
Married woman spurns king’s offer of marriage.
King honors her husband. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Spurned suitor is offered girl by her mother.

He rewards her refusal by a gift of money. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.
Courtier rewarded for resisting princess‘s advances.

When her father learns of the affair he rewards the
courtier and has him marry his daughter. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Reward for long-suffering nun: made abbess of convent.

content: Reward for stoic endurance of pain.
Reward for carrying Christ across a stream.

Christ is in the form of
a child. (St. Christopher.) *Type 768; Dh II 266; Legenda Aurea (ed. Graesse)
432; *Schwickert Zs. f. Vksk. NF III 14--26; Klapper Erzählungen des
Mittelalters 111 No. 101; *Loomis White Magic 114.
child: Boy risks life to carry leper across stream.
Leper is Christ in disguise. Irish myth: Cross.

content: Reward for faith: boy doomed to die saved (miraculously).

child: Reward for service of god, hero, or ascetic for a period.

Old woman gives her only cow believing she would receive a
hundred in return from God.

A bishop hearing
of her faith sends her a hundred cows. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3104, Legends Nos. 198--206;
Greek: Frazer Apollodorus II 280 n. 1.

content: Kindness to orphans repaid by dead parents.

child:
Reward to almsgiving monk given in form of restored honor
and position.

Man pardoned for short accounts when it is learned that he
has given the money to the poor as alms.

One rupee given away for charity incidentally brings back
ten rupees.

content:
Scala Celi 51b, 81b, 83b, 104b, 152b, 158a,
164b Nos. 290, 466, 477, 569, 839, 884, 926; Alphabet No. 368; Irish myth:
*Cross; Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 323 No. 95; Spanish: Espinosa III No.
152, Espinosa Jr. Nos. 181f.; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys;
Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 455, 989; Africa (Loango): Pechuël-Loesche 110,
(Kaffir): Kidd 251 No. 13, (Ekoi): Talbot 208.
child:
Hospitality to disguised
saint (angel, god) rewarded. (Cf. †Q42.3.) *Dh II 133ff.; *bin Gorion Born
Judas@2 I 366; Scala Celi 39b, 81b Nos. 221, 464, 468; Alphabet Nos. 167, 365,
439; Herbert III 392; Literary treatment: Lowell “Vision of Sir Launfal”. -- Irish: Cross, O’Suilleabhain 90; Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 752B*; Spanish: Keller, Espinosa Jr. Nos. 181f.; Greek:
Pauly-Wissowa s.v. “Baukis”; India: *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth:
Malalasekera II 35; Japanese: Anesaki 251f.; N. A. Indian (Maliseet): Mechling
JAFL XXVI 219ff.; Africa (Konnoh): Willans 140.
Three Nephites give blessings as reward for hospitality.

(Mormon tradition.) **H. Lee, The Three Nephites: the
Substance and Significance of the Legend in Folklore (Albuquerque, New Mexico,
1949).
King refuses to invite Patrick to feast.

Poor man kills only cow and uses his only measure of meal
to entertain Patrick. Patrick blesses his wife and son. Irish myth: Cross.

neither he nor his posterity will ever be hurt by venomous
creatures. *Loomis White Magic 131.

Man saves the unrecognized devil from thunder and is
generously rewarded.

Estonian, Swedish,
and Lithuanian: *Balys Tautosakos Darbai VI 27--31; Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.
Revenge given up as reward for hospitality.
Hospitality repaid by attack on devastating enemy.
Hospitality repaid by magic procuring of provisions.

content:
*Roberts 173; Icelandic: Boberg; Breton:
Sébillot Incidents s.v. “politesse”; Missouri French:
Carrière; Spanish: Espinosa III No. 152, Espinosa Jr. Nos. 117, 130, 183;
Italian: Basile Pentamerone IV Nos. 7, 8.
child: Ogre appeased by being called uncle (aunt, etc.).

Cleansing eyelids,
bathing, lousing etc. *Roberts 168; Type 480; Africa (Chaga): Gutmann 132ff.
No. 83, (Alo): Pratt-Chadwick and Lamprey The Alo Man (New York, 1927) 17ff.,
(Batanga): Nassau JAFL XXVIII 45ff. No. 16, (Bulu): Krug JAFL XXV 113 No. 9,
(Bambara): Travélé 205ff. No. 66, (Hausa): Equilbecq Contes indigènes III
291ff., Tremearne Hausa Superstitions and Customs (London, 1913) 424ff. No. 93.

Finnish-Swedish: Hackman FFC VI No. 940*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 941*;
Chinese: Graham.

content:
Jewish: *Neuman; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 83, Africa
(Wakweli): Bender 87f., (Wute): Sieber 197, (Fang): Tessman 196.
child: Knight covers foal with his coat to protect it from storm.
English: Wells 60 (Sire Gawene and the Carle of Carelyle).
Princess given in marriage to clever thief.
Makes him a valet. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Answer rewarded with gold ring; message rewarded with purse
with silver.

content: Reward for attendance on holy man.

(Cf. †Q116.1.) Jewish:
Neuman; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 83, 158, 163f.
Reward for sparing life when in animal form.

child: Ruler tries in vain to intimidate judge.
Rewards him with high post. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Captive knight
freed for having kept his word. Is allowed to leave to collect ransom (or marry
fiancée).

When he returns his captor frees
him (or raises ransom). Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Reward for shielding Mary in childbirth from gaze of
onlookers.

Ruler rewards man‘s love for his captive wife with riches
and freedom.
Ruler rewards captives’ love for each other.

Sets them free and enriches them. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Queen rewards love of man of low lineage by making him an
ambassador.

content: Reward for carrying out dead man’s request.
Reward for ability to keep secrets.

(Cf. †Q144.1.) The
further he must carry water, the greater his heavenly reward. Scala Celi 15a
No. 84; Oesterley No. 80; *A. E. Schönbach Die Legende von Engel und Waldbruder
(Wien, 1901); India: *Thompson-Balys.

(Cf. †V50.) Ward II 621
No. 30; Scala Celi 136b No. 760; Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.
Reward for offering food to crucifix (Madonna).

child: Supplying food to ungrateful stepmother rewarded.

(Cf. †Q151.2.) Africa
(Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 129 No. 23.
